title: The Tastiest Ways to Cook Plantains (Plus How to Slice Them)

steps.title: Heat 1 1⁄2 cups (350 ml) of vegetable oil in a skillet to 375 °F (191 °C).
steps.content: Heat 1 1 ⁄ 2 cups (350 ml) of vegetable oil in a skillet to 375 °F (191 °C). Set a deep skillet on the stove and pour in the vegetable oil. Clip a deep-fry thermometer to the side of the skillet and turn the burner to medium-high heat. Heat the oil until it reaches 375 °F (191 °C). [2] X Research source If the oil continues to heat past 375 °F (191 °C), turn the burner down a little. If you don't have a deep-fry thermometer, heat the oil until it shimmers. When you think it's ready, lower 1 piece of plantain into the oil. If the oil is hot enough, it will immediately begin to bubble and fry. If it doesn't, wait another minute and check again.

steps.title: Place 4 or 5 pieces of plantains into the hot oil.
steps.content: Place 4 or 5 pieces of plantains into the hot oil. Set 4 large plantains that you've sliced into 1 inch (2.5 cm) pieces on your cutting board. Use your hands to slowly lower 4 or 5 of these pieces into the oil, taking care not to drop them or the oil could splash you. [3] X Research source If you're concerned that the oil will burn you, place the plantain pieces on a slotted spoon and lower it directly into the oil. It's important to fry the plantains in batches so the temperature of the oil doesn't drop quickly.

steps.title: Fry the plantains for 4 to 5 minutes.
steps.content: Fry the plantains for 4 to 5 minutes. Set a timer and let the plantain pieces fry until they're a rich golden brown. Use a slotted spatula or spoon to carefully flip them over halfway through the frying time. This ensures that they become crispy and brown on both sides. [4] X Research source Lower the burner temperature if the plantains are browning too fast.

steps.title: Transfer the fried plantains to a paper towel-lined plate.
steps.content: Transfer the fried plantains to a paper towel-lined plate. Take the slotted spatula or spoon and carefully move the fried plantains to a lined plate. The paper towel will absorb excess grease. [5] X Research source Remember to let the oil heat back up to 375 °F (191 °C) before you fry another batch of plantains.

steps.title: Sprinkle a little salt or sugar over the plantains.
steps.content: Sprinkle a little salt or sugar over the plantains. Season the fried plantains any way you like or leave them plain. Enjoy the plantains while they're hot since they won't store well. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Preheat the oven to 425 °F (218 °C) and line a sheet with parchment paper.
steps.content: Preheat the oven to 425 °F (218 °C) and line a sheet with parchment paper. Set a rimmed baking sheet on your work surface and tear off a piece of parchment paper. Lay the paper on the sheet and set it aside. [8] X Research source If you don't have parchment paper, you could lay down a silicone matt or spray the sheet with nonstick cooking spray.

steps.title: Stir the plantain pieces in a bowl with butter, sugar, and salt.
steps.content: Stir the plantain pieces in a bowl with butter, sugar, and salt. Place 2 ripe plantains that you've sliced into 1 inch (2.5 cm) pieces into a mixing bowl. Add 1 tablespoon (14 g) of melted butter or oil, 1 teaspoon (4 g) of sugar, and 1 pinch of salt. Then, use a spoon to toss the mixture gently until the plantains are coated. If you prefer, use your favorite vegetable oil instead of butter. If you don't want the plantains to be sweet, you can leave the sugar out.

steps.title: Lay the seasoned plantain pieces on the sheet.
steps.content: Lay the seasoned plantain pieces on the sheet. Transfer the pieces to the parchment-lined sheet and arrange them so they're in a single layer. Ensure that there's at least 1 ⁄ 2 inch (1.3 cm) of space between each piece so they roast evenly. There's no need to grease the parchment since it contains silicone. This prevents the plantains from sticking.

steps.title: Bake the plantains for 10 to 12 minutes.
steps.content: Bake the plantains for 10 to 12 minutes. Put the sheet in the oven and roast the plantains until they become completely soft. Cook the plantains until they turn a rich brown color. Then, serve them while they're hot. [9] X Research source Baked plantains are a great dessert or side dish for a rich meal. [10] X Expert Source Randall Chambers Personal Chef Expert Interview. 26 October 2021.

steps.title: Melt the butter with the oil in a skillet.
steps.content: Melt the butter with the oil in a skillet. Put 2 tablespoons (28 g) of butter into a large skillet on the stove. Add 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of canola oil and turn the burner to medium-low. [11] X Research source Stir the butter occasionally to help it mix with the oil. Substitute coconut oil for a slightly tropical flavor.

steps.title: Place plantain pieces into the skillet.
steps.content: Place plantain pieces into the skillet. Take 2 plantains that you've sliced into 1 ⁄ 2 inch (1.3 cm) pieces and lay them in the skillet. Arrange the slices so they're in a single layer and aren't overlapping. [12] X Research source If you'd like to cook more than 2 plantains, sauté them in batches.

steps.title: Sauté the plantains for 10 to 12 minutes and turn them every few minutes.
steps.content: Sauté the plantains for 10 to 12 minutes and turn them every few minutes. Keep the burner at medium-low so the plantains don't brown too quickly. Use a spatula or spoon to flip the plantains over every few minutes and cook them until they're golden brown on both sides. [13] X Research source The plantains will also soften as they sauté.

steps.title: Turn off the burner and serve the plantains with their buttery sauce.
steps.content: Turn off the burner and serve the plantains with their buttery sauce. Spoon the plantains onto a serving plate and carefully pour the butter that's left in the skillet over the slices. Then, serve them plain or sprinkle a little salt or sugar over them. [14] X Research source For the best flavor and texture, eat the plantains immediately.

steps.title: Select plantains according to how sweet you like them.
steps.content: Select plantains according to how sweet you like them. You've probably seen plantains that are almost black at the market or grocery store. These are the ripest, so they're the sweetest. If you prefer them less sweet, look for a plantain that's mostly yellow with some black spots. Green plantains are the firmest and least sweet, so you might choose these if you want a more savory dish. [15] X Research source You can usually find plantains near the bananas at the grocery store. Although plantains are similar, they contain more starch and less sugar than bananas.

steps.title: Trim 1 inch (2.5 cm) from each end of the plantains.
steps.content: Trim 1 inch (2.5 cm) from each end of the plantains. To make it easier to peel a plantain, take a sharp knife and carefully cut off each end. Discard the stem and tip of each plantain. [16] X Research source Avoid bending the stem to peel it back. A plantain's peel is thicker than a banana's so you can't peel them the same way.

steps.title: Cut lengthwise through the peel.
steps.content: Cut lengthwise through the peel. Hold the plantain in place on your cutting board and carefully make a thin slit from 1 end of the plantain down to the opposite end. Ensure that you only cut through the peel and not through the plantain's flesh. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Pull away the peel.
steps.content: Pull away the peel. Use your fingers to pull the peel away from the plantain flesh. This is easier to do with a very ripe plantain, which will almost fall away on its own. If you made 2 slits on a green plantain, pull both sides of the peel away from the flesh in opposite directions. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Slice the plantain into 1⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) or 1 inch (2.5 cm) pieces.
steps.content: Slice the plantain into 1 ⁄ 2 inch (1.3 cm) or 1 inch (2.5 cm) pieces. Read the recipe you're using to determine how large to cut your plantain pieces. Most recipes recommend that you cut across the plantain to make lots of 1 ⁄ 2 inch (1.3 cm) or 1 inch (2.5 cm) pieces. [19] X Research source If you like, slice the plantain diagonally. This increases the surface area of the plantains so they become crispier and more flavorful.
